s.text: The eight ages in which these bridges, windows, and gateways appear are Classical, Romanesque, Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque, and Rococo, the age of iron and glass architecture, and the age of modern architecture.

The windows and gates represent the spirit of openness and cooperation of the new confederation, we are told, while the bridge is a metaphor, as Bill Clinton showed, guaranteed not to go over the heads of the populace of any continent.

The winning designer went for the "ages and styles" theme, interpreted as such stock architectural elements as bridges, windows, and gateways.

These are not, mind you, actual existing bridges, like London Bridge or the Pont Neuf, but are "generic, and cannot be attributed to any particular place in any single country."

According to the Maastricht Treaty, the currency will be put into circulation only after individual national economies have hit certain "targets"--such as a sufficiently low ratio of debt to gross domestic product.

It is not easy.

More specifically, according to the literature, the bridge "epitomizes the dawn of the new common Europe with its common cultural heritage and the vision of a common future in the next century, indeed, the new millennium."
But for all their color and utopian promise, the new notes are lifeless.
The very designs on the bills--such as the fortresslike Treasury that appears on our $10 note--seem to promise a happy future of redemption amid prosperity.
